text: My soul breaketh for the longing that it hath unto thy judgments at all times.
text_kjv: My soul breaketh for the longing that it hath unto thy judgments at all times.
text_niv: My soul is consumed with longingfor your laws at all times.
text_esv: My soul is consumed with longing for your rules  at all times.
text_nlt: I am always overwhelmedwith a desire for your regulations.
text_msg: My soul is starved and hungry, ravenous!—insatiable for your nourishing commands.
text_nasb: My soul is crushed with longing After Your ordinances at all times.
context: Psalm 119 is an acrostic poem, likely composed by a single author deeply devoted to the Torah. Its precise historical context is debated, but it is generally believed to have been written after the Babylonian exile. This period saw a renewed emphasis on adherence to God's law as a means of maintaining Jewish identity and securing divine favor. The 'judgments' (mishpatim) referred to in this verse aren't just legal rulings, but encompass the entirety of God's righteous decrees, principles, and ways. The psalm reflects a longing for God's law to permeate every aspect of life, in contrast to the perceived moral failings that led to the exile. The 'soul' (nephesh) represents the whole person, including emotions, will, and intellect. The verb 'breaketh' or 'is consumed' paints a picture of intense, almost unbearable, desire. Understanding this verse requires appreciating the post-exilic context where faithfulness to God's law was seen as crucial for national restoration and individual righteousness. The Psalmist wasn't simply intellectually assenting to God's law; he was emotionally and spiritually consumed by a deep longing for it to be realized in his life and the world around him. This wasn't a casual preference but a passionate, all-consuming desire mirroring the devotion expected of those covenanting with God.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 119:20 reveals a heart profoundly oriented towards God. The psalmist's 'soul breaketh' signifies a yearning that transcends mere intellectual agreement or dutiful obedience. It speaks of a deep, visceral longing akin to a physical hunger or thirst, but directed towards spiritual nourishment found in God's judgments. This intense desire suggests a belief that true life, fulfillment, and purpose are inextricably linked to understanding and living in accordance with God's will. The 'judgments' are not seen as burdensome restrictions but as pathways to righteousness and flourishing. The fact that this longing exists 'at all times' indicates a persistent and unwavering devotion. It’s not a fleeting emotion but a constant state of being. This verse challenges the common misconception that obedience to God is merely a matter of external compliance. Instead, it emphasizes the importance of internal transformation and a heart that genuinely desires God's ways. The psalmist's longing illustrates a crucial aspect of spiritual maturity: a movement from obligation to passionate desire in our relationship with God. It highlights the profound truth that God's laws, when understood and embraced, become a source of joy, freedom, and deep satisfaction. The depth of this longing also indicates a recognition of one's own inherent sinfulness and dependence on God's grace to live righteously. The psalmist sees God's judgments not as unattainable ideals but as the very means by which he can be transformed and conformed to God's image.
application: In contemporary life, Psalm 119:20 challenges us to examine the true desires of our hearts. Are we truly longing for God's will to be done in our lives, or are we content with a superficial faith? The verse calls us to cultivate a deeper, more passionate pursuit of God's Word, not just as a matter of duty, but out of a genuine desire to know Him and His ways. We can apply this verse practically by: 1) Prioritizing daily time in God's Word, not just reading but meditating on its meaning and application. 2) Praying for a deeper understanding of God's character and will as revealed in Scripture. 3) Examining our motives for obedience. Are we seeking to please God or merely to follow religious rules? 4) Seeking community with other believers who share a passion for God's Word and can encourage us in our pursuit. 5) Intentionally seeking ways to apply God's principles in our daily lives, in our relationships, in our work, and in our choices. We can also use this verse as a catalyst for self-reflection. Are we willing to allow God's Word to challenge our assumptions, confront our biases, and transform our thinking? Do we truly believe that God's way is the best way, even when it conflicts with our own desires or the prevailing culture? Cultivating this longing is a lifelong process. It requires intentionality, perseverance, and a willingness to surrender our own will to God's. However, the rewards are immeasurable: a deeper relationship with God, a greater sense of purpose, and a life that is truly fulfilling and aligned with His will. Embracing this verse means actively cultivating a hunger for God's truth that surpasses all other desires.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that often my longing for worldly things far outweighs my longing for You and Your Word. Forgive me for the times I have treated Your judgments as a burden rather than a blessing. I ask that You would ignite within me a burning desire for Your truth. Help me to understand Your character and Your will as revealed in Scripture. Grant me the grace to surrender my own desires to Your perfect plan. Fill me with a hunger and thirst for righteousness, that my soul might break with longing for Your ways. Teach me to find joy and satisfaction in obeying Your commands. May my life be a testament to my love for You and Your Word. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The word 'break' signifies an intense, overwhelming desire, almost a desperation. It suggests a deep emotional and spiritual yearning that consumes the person, reflecting a profound love and hunger for God's judgments.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean for my soul to 'break' in longing?

faqs.answer: The plural 'judgments' refers to the totality of God's laws, decrees, and righteous standards. It encompasses the various applications of God's principles to different areas of life, a multifaceted expression of His singular truth.
faqs.question: Q2: Why are 'judgments' plural? Doesn't God have one standard?

faqs.answer: Cultivating this longing involves consistent Bible reading and meditation, prayer for understanding, seeking community with like-minded believers, and intentionally applying God's principles to your daily life. It requires commitment and openness.
faqs.question: Q3: How can I cultivate this kind of intense longing for God's Word?

faqs.answer: Yes, it is possible. As you grow in your relationship with God and understand the wisdom and goodness behind His commands, you can begin to appreciate them as pathways to true freedom and fulfillment, fostering that longing.
faqs.question: Q4: Is it possible to genuinely long for God's judgments when they seem difficult?

faqs.answer: While Psalm 119 emphasizes the importance of obedience, it also points to a need for grace. The longing for God's judgments implies a recognition of one's inability to perfectly fulfill them, highlighting reliance on God's mercy and empowerment.
